refnamediv.refpurpose: The tree interface used by GtkTreeView

refsect1.para: GtkTreeModel is implemented by GtkTreeModelSort, GtkTreeStore, GtkListStore and GtkTreeModelFilter.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The GtkTreeModel interface defines a generic tree interface for use by the GtkTreeView widget. It is an abstract interface, and is designed to be usable with any appropriate data structure. The programmer just has to implement this interface on their own data type for it to be viewable by a GtkTreeView widget.

The model is represented as a hierarchical tree of strongly-typed, columned data. In other words, the model can be seen as a tree where every node has different values depending on which column is being queried. The type of data found in a column is determined by using the GType system (ie. G_TYPE_INT, GTK_TYPE_BUTTON, G_TYPE_POINTER, etc.). The types are homogeneous per column across all nodes. It is important to note that this interface only provides a way of examining a model and observing changes. The implementation of each individual model decides how and if changes are made.

In order to make life simpler for programmers who do not need to write their own specialized model, two generic models are provided — the GtkTreeStore and the GtkListStore. To use these, the developer simply pushes data into these models as necessary. These models provide the data structure as well as all appropriate tree interfaces. As a result, implementing drag and drop, sorting, and storing data is trivial. For the vast majority of trees and lists, these two models are sufficient.

Models are accessed on a node/column level of granularity. One can query for the value of a model at a certain node and a certain column on that node. There are two structures used to reference a particular node in a model. They are the GtkTreePath and the GtkTreeIter
Here, iter is short for iterator
Most of the interface consists of operations on a GtkTreeIter.

A path is essentially a potential node. It is a location on a model that may or may not actually correspond to a node on a specific model. The GtkTreePath struct can be converted into either an array of unsigned integers or a string. The string form is a list of numbers separated by a colon. Each number refers to the offset at that level. Thus, the path 0 refers to the root node and the path 2:4 refers to the fifth child of the third node.

By contrast, a GtkTreeIter is a reference to a specific node on a specific model. It is a generic struct with an integer and three generic pointers. These are filled in by the model in a model-specific way. One can convert a path to an iterator by calling gtk_tree_model_get_iter(). These iterators are the primary way of accessing a model and are similar to the iterators used by GtkTextBuffer. They are generally statically allocated on the heap and only used for a short time. The model interface defines a set of operations using them for navigating the model.

It is expected that models fill in the iterator with private data. For example, the GtkListStore model, which is internally a simple linked list, stores a list node in one of the pointers. The GtkTreeModelSort stores an array and an offset in two of the pointers. Additionally, there is an integer field. This field is generally filled with a unique stamp per model. This stamp is for catching errors resulting from using invalid iterators with a model.

The lifecycle of an iterator can be a little confusing at first. Iterators are expected to always be valid for as long as the model is unchanged (and doesn't emit a signal). The model is considered to own all outstanding iterators and nothing needs to be done to free them from the user's point of view. Additionally, some models guarantee that an iterator is valid for as long as the node it refers to is valid (most notably the GtkTreeStore and GtkListStore). Although generally uninteresting, as one always has to allow for the case where iterators do not persist beyond a signal, some very important performance enhancements were made in the sort model. As a result, the GTK_TREE_MODEL_ITERS_PERSIST flag was added to indicate this behavior.

To help show some common operation of a model, some examples are provided. The first example shows three ways of getting the iter at the location 3:2:5. While the first method shown is easier, the second is much more common, as you often get paths from callbacks.

refsect2.title: struct GtkTreeIter
refsect2.para: The GtkTreeIter is the primary structure for accessing a structure. Models are expected to put a unique integer in the stamp member, and put model-specific data in the three user_data members.

listitem.simpara: A unique stamp to catch invalid iterators

refsect2.title: struct GtkTreeModelIface
enum GtkTreeModelFlags
refsect2.para: These flags indicate various properties of a GtkTreeModel. They are returned by gtk_tree_model_get_flags(), and must be static for the lifetime of the object. A more complete description of GTK_TREE_MODEL_ITERS_PERSIST can be found in the overview of this section.

listitem.simpara: Iterators survive all signals emitted by the tree.
The model is a list only, and never has children

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new GtkTreePath. This structure refers to a row.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_new_from_string ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new GtkTreePath initialized to path. path is expected to be a colon separated list of numbers. For example, the string "10:4:0" would create a path of depth 3 pointing to the 11th child of the root node, the 5th child of that 11th child, and the 1st child of that 5th child. If an invalid path string is passed in, NULL is returned.

listitem.simpara: The string representation of a path.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_new_from_indices ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new path with first_index and varargs as indices.
Since 2.2

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_to_string ()
refsect2.para: Generates a string representation of the path. This string is a ':' separated list of numbers. For example, "4:10:0:3" would be an acceptable return value for this string.

listitem.simpara: A newly-allocated string. Must be freed with g_free().

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_new_first ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new GtkTreePath. The string representation of this path is "0"

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_new_root()

warning.para: gtk_tree_path_new_root is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: An alternate name for gtk_tree_path_new_iter() provided for compatibility reasons; this macro will be deprecated in future versions of GTK+.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_append_index ()
refsect2.para: Appends a new index to a path. As a result, the depth of the path is increased.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_prepend_index ()
refsect2.para: Prepends a new index to a path. As a result, the depth of the path is increased.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_get_depth ()
refsect2.para: Returns the current depth of path.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_get_indices ()
refsect2.para: Returns the current indices of path. This is an array of integers, each representing a node in a tree. This value should not be freed.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_free ()
refsect2.para: Frees path.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_copy ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new GtkTreePath as a copy of path.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_compare ()
refsect2.para: Compares two paths. If a appears before b in a tree, then -1 is returned. If b appears before a, then 1 is returned. If the two nodes are equal, then 0 is returned.

listitem.simpara: The relative positions of a and b

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_next ()
refsect2.para: Moves the path to point to the next node at the current depth.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_prev ()
refsect2.para: Moves the path to point to the previous node at the current depth, if it exists.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if path has a previous node, and the move was made.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_up ()
refsect2.para: Moves the path to point to its parent node, if it has a parent.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if path has a parent, and the move was made.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_down ()
refsect2.para: Moves path to point to the first child of the current path.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_is_ancestor ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if descendant is a descendant of path.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if descendant is contained inside path

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_path_is_descendant ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if path is a descendant of ancestor.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if ancestor contains path somewhere below it

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a row reference based on path. This reference will keep pointing to the node pointed to by path, so long as it exists. It listens to all signals emitted by model, and updates its path appropriately. If path isn't a valid path in model, then NULL is returned.

listitem.simpara: A newly allocated GtkTreeRowReference, or NULL

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_new_proxy ()
refsect2.para: You do not need to use this function. Creates a row reference based on path. This reference will keep pointing to the node pointed to by path, so long as it exists. If path isn't a valid path in model, then NULL is returned. However, unlike references created with gtk_tree_row_reference_new(), it does not listen to the model for changes. The creator of the row reference must do this explicitly using gtk_tree_row_reference_inserted(), gtk_tree_row_reference_deleted(), gtk_tree_row_reference_reordered().

These functions must be called exactly once per proxy when the corresponding signal on the model is emitted. This single call updates all row references for that proxy. Since built-in GTK+ objects like GtkTreeView already use this mechanism internally, using them as the proxy object will produce unpredictable results. Further more, passing the same object as model and proxy doesn't work for reasons of internal implementation.
This type of row reference is primarily meant by structures that need to carefully monitor exactly when a row_reference updates itself, and is not generally needed by most applications.

listitem.simpara: A newly allocated GtkTreeRowReference, or NULL

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_get_path ()
refsect2.para: Returns a path that the row reference currently points to, or NULL if the path pointed to is no longer valid.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_valid ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if the reference is non-NULL and refers to a current valid path.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if reference points to a valid path.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_free ()
refsect2.para: Free's reference. reference may be NULL.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_copy ()
refsect2.para: Copies a GtkTreeRowReference.
Since 2.2

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_inserted ()
refsect2.para: Lets a set of row reference created by gtk_tree_row_reference_new_proxy() know that the model emitted the "row_inserted" signal.

listitem.simpara: The row position that was inserted

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_deleted ()
refsect2.para: Lets a set of row reference created by gtk_tree_row_reference_new_proxy() know that the model emitted the "row_deleted" signal.

listitem.simpara: The path position that was deleted

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_row_reference_reordered ()
refsect2.para: Lets a set of row reference created by gtk_tree_row_reference_new_proxy() know that the model emitted the "rows_reordered" signal.

listitem.simpara: The parent path of the reordered signal
The iter pointing to the parent of the reordered

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_iter_copy ()
refsect2.para: Creates a dynamically allocated tree iterator as a copy of iter. This function is not intended for use in applications, because you can just copy the structs by value (GtkTreeIter new_iter = iter;). You must free this iter with gtk_tree_iter_free().

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_iter_free ()
refsect2.para: Frees an iterator that has been allocated on the heap. This function is mainly used for language bindings.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_flags ()
refsect2.para: Returns a set of flags supported by this interface. The flags are a bitwise combination of GtkTreeModelFlags. The flags supported should not change during the lifecycle of the tree_model.

listitem.simpara: The flags supported by this interface.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_n_columns ()
refsect2.para: Returns the number of columns supported by tree_model.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_column_type ()
refsect2.para: Returns the type of the column.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_iter ()
refsect2.para: Sets iter to a valid iterator pointing to path.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_iter_from_string ()
refsect2.para: Sets iter to a valid iterator pointing to path_string, if it exists. Otherwise, iter is left invalid and FALSE is returned.

listitem.simpara: A string representation of a GtkTreePath.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_iter_first ()
refsect2.para: Initializes iter with the first iterator in the tree (the one at the path "0") and returns TRUE. Returns FALSE if the tree is empty.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_iter_root()

warning.para: gtk_tree_model_get_iter_root is deprecated and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: A alternate name for gtk_tree_model_get_iter_first() provided for compatibility reasons; this macro will be deprecated in future versions of GTK+.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_path ()
refsect2.para: Returns a newly-created GtkTreePath referenced by iter. This path should be freed with gtk_tree_path_free().

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_value ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gtk_tree_model_get_value (GtkTreeModel *tree_model, GtkTreeIter *iter, gint column, GValue *value);
refsect2.para: Sets initializes and sets value to that at column. When done with value, g_value_unset() needs to be called to free any allocated memory.

listitem.simpara: The column to lookup the value at.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_iter_next ()
refsect2.para: Sets iter to point to the node following it at the current level. If there is no next iter, FALSE is returned and iter is set to be invalid.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if iter has been changed to the next node.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_iter_children ()
refsect2.para: Sets iter to point to the first child of parent. If parent has no children, FALSE is returned and iter is set to be invalid. parent will remain a valid node after this function has been called.
If parent is NULL returns the first node, equivalent to gtk_tree_model_get_iter_first (tree_model, iter);

listitem.simpara: The new GtkTreeIter to be set to the child.
TRUE, if child has been set to the first child.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_iter_has_child ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if iter has children, FALSE otherwise.

listitem.simpara: The GtkTreeIter to test for children.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_iter_n_children ()
refsect2.para: Returns the number of children that iter has. As a special case, if iter is NULL, then the number of toplevel nodes is returned.

listitem.simpara: The number of children of iter.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_iter_nth_child ()
refsect2.programlisting: gboolean gtk_tree_model_iter_nth_child (GtkTreeModel *tree_model, GtkTreeIter *iter, GtkTreeIter *parent, gint n);
refsect2.para: Sets iter to be the child of parent, using the given index. The first index is 0. If n is too big, or parent has no children, iter is set to an invalid iterator and FALSE is returned. parent will remain a valid node after this function has been called. As a special case, if parent is NULL, then the nth root node is set.

listitem.simpara: The GtkTreeIter to set to the nth child.
The GtkTreeIter to get the child from, or NULL.
Then index of the desired child.
TRUE, if parent has an nth child.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_iter_parent ()
refsect2.para: Sets iter to be the parent of child. If child is at the toplevel, and doesn't have a parent, then iter is set to an invalid iterator and FALSE is returned. child will remain a valid node after this function has been called.

listitem.simpara: The new GtkTreeIter to set to the parent.
TRUE, if iter is set to the parent of child.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_string_from_iter ()
refsect2.para: Generates a string representation of the iter. This string is a ':' separated list of numbers. For example, "4:10:0:3" would be an acceptable return value for this string.

listitem.simpara: A newly-allocated string. Must be freed with g_free().

refsect2.para: Since 2.2

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_ref_node ()
refsect2.para: Lets the tree ref the node. This is an optional method for models to implement. To be more specific, models may ignore this call as it exists primarily for performance reasons.

This function is primarily meant as a way for views to let caching model know when nodes are being displayed (and hence, whether or not to cache that node.) For example, a file-system based model would not want to keep the entire file-hierarchy in memory, just the sections that are currently being displayed by every current view.
A model should be expected to be able to get an iter independent of its reffed state.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_unref_node ()
refsect2.para: Lets the tree unref the node. This is an optional method for models to implement. To be more specific, models may ignore this call as it exists primarily for performance reasons.
For more information on what this means, see gtk_tree_model_ref_node(). Please note that nodes that are deleted are not unreffed.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get ()
refsect2.para: Gets the value of one or more cells in the row referenced by iter. The variable argument list should contain integer column numbers, each column number followed by a place to store the value being retrieved. The list is terminated by a -1. For example, to get a value from column 0 with type G_TYPE_STRING, you would write: gtk_tree_model_get (model, iter, 0, &place_string_here, -1), where place_string_here is a gchar* to be filled with the string. If appropriate, the returned values have to be freed or unreferenced.

listitem.simpara: pairs of column number and value return locations, terminated by -1

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_get_valist ()
refsect2.para: See gtk_tree_model_get(), this version takes a va_list for language bindings to use.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_foreach ()
refsect2.para: Calls func on each node in model in a depth-first fashion. If func returns TRUE, then the tree ceases to be walked, and gtk_tree_model_foreach() returns.

listitem.simpara: A function to be called on each row
User data to passed to func.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_row_changed ()
refsect2.para: Emits the "row_changed" signal on tree_model.

listitem.simpara: A GtkTreePath pointing to the changed row
A valid GtkTreeIter pointing to the changed row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_row_inserted ()
refsect2.para: Emits the "row_inserted" signal on tree_model

listitem.simpara: A GtkTreePath pointing to the inserted row
A valid GtkTreeIter pointing to the inserted row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_row_has_child_toggled ()
refsect2.para: Emits the "row_has_child_toggled" signal on tree_model. This should be called by models after the child state of a node changes.

listitem.simpara: A GtkTreePath pointing to the changed row
A valid GtkTreeIter pointing to the changed row

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_row_deleted ()
refsect2.para: Emits the "row_deleted" signal on tree_model. This should be called by models after a row has been removed. The location pointed to by path should be the location that the row previously was at. It may not be a valid location anymore.

listitem.simpara: A GtkTreePath pointing to the previous location of the deleted row.

refsect2.title: gtk_tree_model_rows_reordered ()
refsect2.para: Emits the "rows_reordered" signal on tree_model. This should be called by models when their rows have been reordered.

listitem.simpara: A GtkTreePath pointing to the tree node whose children have been reordered
A valid GtkTreeIter pointing to the node whose children have been reordered
an array of integers mapping the current position of each child to its old position before the re-ordering, i.e. new_order[newpos] = oldpos.
